awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Discoveries in multiphase detonations: Fuel droplet processing at extreme conditions
awd_abstract_narration:
Combustion of storable, liquid fuels is common in everyday life, powering cars, trains, airplanes, and ships. The combustion efficiency in these engines depends on the reaction rate. As the reaction rate becomes faster, the combustion front propagates faster and can exceed the speed of sound, in a process known as a detonation wave. Combustion devices operating with detonation waves can yield much higher efficiencies compared to traditional engines. In liquid fueled detonation engines, fuel droplets, about the size of a red blood cell, must be broken up, evaporated, and reacted over few nanoseconds. In this project, a combination of new experimental and simulation methods will be used to better understand liquid fuel break up process and to develop a new model for the burning of fuel droplets in a detonation wave. The model developed can be used to improve the design of engines for civilian and defense applications. 

The overall goal of this project is to understand how 2-20 nanometer fuel droplets undergo simultaneous hydrodynamic breakup, vaporization, and reaction (SBVR) under detonation conditions. For this purpose, a new SBVR model will be developed and tested with fully resolved microscale simulations, and mesoscale multiphase detonation tube experiments and simulations. Microscale simulations will be performed using an in-house simulation code, IMPACT, based on the ghost fluid method. The SBVR model will be implemented on Lagrangian point particles in the open source hydrodynamics code, FLASH to simulate mesoscale experiments. Experiments will be conducted using the multiphase detonation tube facility. The key tasks to be conducted include, (i) investigations of simultaneous droplet breakup, phase change, and reaction in microscale simulations; (ii) measurement of detonation properties for various fuel droplet sizes using detonation tube experiments; and (iii) development and testing the SBVR model using experimental and mesoscale simulations data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to understand how small-scale fuel droplet mixing occurs under detonation conditions that may occur in pulsed or rotating detonation engines. Multiphase detonations involving liquid droplets is a fundamental problem in the development of high-speed, high efficiency flight technologies. Passenger air travel, relying primarily on the Brayton cycle, contributes significantly to our carbon foot print and is one of the fastest growing sources of global carbon emissions. Such pressure-gain combustion engines can also be used for stationary electric power generation (combined cycles) and for propulsion applications in aircraft, rocket motors, and naval vessels. To be practical in these propulsion applications, detonation engines will need to be powered by high density liquid fuels, while challenging multiphase effects must be considered in their design. In contrast to gas-phase combustion which have been widely studied, our understanding of liquid-fuel detonations is still in its early stages.

In this project, we have performed a detailed investigation of how liquid fuel droplet that are admitted into a detonation chamber evolve and combust under the harsh conditions. The intellectual merit of this work thus lies in developing a novel integrated simulation and experimental framework that spans the scales of interest and advances our understanding of droplet reactions under extreme conditions. Our simulation techniques are capable of resolving for the first time, the detailed interfacial phenomena that might occur on the surface of a micron-sized droplet, playing a role in the overall fragmentation and combustion of such droplets. These include a wide range of physics such as droplet deformation due to aerodynamic forces, droplet breakup due to instability growth and surface tension and viscous effects which are captured here with their temperature-dependent behaviors, phase change occurring at the droplet interface, and combustion of evaporated fuel vapors. Such phenomena are beyond the resolution capabilities of current experimental diagnostic techniques.

Our simulations show the droplet undergoes significant deformation and morphological changes following shock impingement, as the droplet surface becomes unstable to the Kelvin-Helmholtz instability. The droplet core is also observed to eject a thin liquid sheet that determines its late-time behavior, and has not been observed previously. As the droplet evaporates, a layer of fuel vapor is formed surrounding the droplet which also affects the growth of surface instabilities at late-times. In addition, the evaporation of fuel vapor induces an blow off flow which leads to droplet cooling. Thus, a significant finding from our study is that the evaporation and droplet morphological evolution are two-way coupled, and this effect must be taken into account in the development of simpler (low-order) models of this process.

As the fuel vapors react, a diffusion flame is formed surrounding the droplet, leading to intense droplet heating and further enhanced droplet vapor production. However, the flame is not uniformly distributed surrounding the droplet, leaving regions of unburned fuel vapor. If the reactivity of the fuel vapor is increased (say through the addition of a catalyst), we also observe secondary burning in the wake region of the droplet, eventually causing the flame to reattach to the droplet. Thus, the evolution of the droplet impinged by a shock or detonation wave is highly spatially inhomogeneous, which must be taken into account in the development of more accurate models of detonation engines. The results from our work can be used in developing or refining drag and evaporation laws, and droplet deformation models for shock-processed fuel droplets; such models are used as subgrid models in system-level simulations of detonation phenomena occurring in detonation engines, or modeling multiphase explosive behaviors occurring in nature.
